yorum: At my request, T-Mobile processed a suspension of my T-mobile home internet service and promised the monthly fee would be reduced from $50 to $10. Review of T-Mobile Home Internet 15-Day Test DriveService Start: I began the 15-day trial with T-Mobile Home Internet in November. Initially, the service was poor, but after some adjustments, it significantly improved. I was impressed with the speed and quality of the service, to the point where I considered switching my lines from Xfinity to T-Mobile. However, due to the complexity of the process, I decided to cancel.Cancellation Process: I spoke with customer service, and they recommended canceling within the 15-day period, which I did. I received a return label for the equipment and sent it back before the deadline.Subsequent Issues: On November 29, I received a letter from the collections department for $55 with no explanation. I never received a bill from T-Mobile for this amount. Then, on December 9, 2024, I received another letter from a collection agency in PA for the same $55. Finally, on December 14, I received a bill for $32.66 for internet usage, despite having returned the equipment on time.Reflection: I am referring this case to the consumer protection department in the state of Oregon for review. It is concerning that a large company like T-Mobile uses tactics like these without following proper procedures. I hope that with advances in artificial intelligence, new companies with better services and more transparent practices will emerge, eliminating the need to deal with situations like this.

They ask the same questions over and over without logging the information or history. Cannot play video games etc- we lose internet continuously. After about a month , a different customer support said they would have continuous connectivity with our tower ( shouldn't it be already?) They say the same thing about the towers...And still the same issues again and again. Every time we call they ask the same questions wasting 20 or 30 minutes at a time like, our address, phone numbers etc...we have gotten hung up on or dropped from calls just to do it again. Once we have the opportunity we are changing our service to another company.After our call just today 3 January 2025 the lady finally admitted we were too far from our tower- so everyone else before knew that and kept taking our money. We only got one 1/2 of a month refund after complaining our faces off and now we finally know what the real issue is after 3 months! Apparently we are supposed to "call back if we have continuous problems from here further" Ridiculous and dishonest for them to obviously k own we wouldn't have connectivity where we are yet they allowed us to sign up. Total waste of time.

I was previously a T-Mobile customer for years. They kept increasing the bill, and the customer service continued to be lower. The phone prices and incentives were less and less. I got really tired of paying full price for a new phone every two years and not getting a discount or any kind of incentive for my kiddos phone line. I had my phone fully paid off and I didn't have any other equipment? I tried to call customer service and they said they couldn't help me without some six digit pin. I had no idea what it was because I never use a pin when I call they verify me through a text message. When I escalated the call to a supervisor, the supervisor basically said they couldn't help me either and I had to go into a T-Mobile store with my ID to be verified. I understand having security measures but when you're not even a customer anymore and you can't even have a manager tell you what the charge is for over the phone and that's the only information you're requesting that is a broken system. I offered to give my drivers license number my Social Security number my email address, have an email verification, and five other solutions but they refused to do anything without some obscure pin I don't even remember making when I first signed up..Needless to say, I will never use this service again and I don't recommend anyone else comes here unless you want to overpay for your phones and not be able to be helped with your bill.I say this as somebody who works in customer support, and knows how systems can be created to truly help people.

Honestly,  had a great experience up to 9/24-9/26.I have recently had lost my job and had a temporary part time job and had made a payment arragement that I really thought I could make it work.When I realized I would not be able to pay I called,  spoke to a rep. I'm using chat,  had to go through the process all over,  get nothing but tolf to call the 1888 number because the hurricane might change that.   I call and start the process AGAIN.   Nope,  can't help me.   I guess knowing a customer out there who might not be able to contact loved ones in a deadly weather emergency is A OK morally.At this point,  I'm just curious if my phones are paid off,  because this isn't ok. By 4pm still hadn't heard anything,  so started a chat with a rep 6 who HAS TO START THE PROCESS OVER and informs me that my letter was rejected (wasn't informed at all) and after a pissed off conversation,  I'm approved to pay 50$ on Friday, the suspension free is waived (60$) and i could make an arrangement for the rest.Final day 9/26:  I get paid early,  i start up a chat to pay the 50$ that I was promised abs told to pay.AND I HAVE TO START THE PROCESS OVER.I now am expected to pay the past due amount (not the 50$). And "chat" rep says they're "limited" in what they can do.   I literally show her screenshots of what was promised.Now they tell me to wait 24 hours for approval.  I cussed her out.I end up calling the 611 number and start the process for the 8th time.   I no longer have to 50$, i no longer have the 60$ service fee taken off and the "computer" can't even help me with the arragement (the dates aren't what I said I can do).Is some of this my fault? ABSOLUTELY.My issue is the lack of detail note taking that assists with helping reps deal with customers who have been speaking to several people.My issue is the lack of transparency when one rep says something can be done and it can't be done by another one.My issue is the lack of flexibility that reps used to have to assist customers whose lives just got slammed with too much stuff at once.Asking your customers to beg friends and family for money is not ok.  That customer may not have a friend or family.   There are people without support systems.Leaving your reps as shark bait for upset customers is a really crappy thing to do to employees.An inflexible computer system that doesn't leave any places for reps to assist with customer service leads to irate customers.After this experience I felt unseen,  not listened to,  and unimportant.That's why I'm leaving.

T-Mobile is not allowed to take and sell your personal information as a telephone service provider.  So T-Mobile invented T-Mobile Tuesdays (a ‚Äúgift‚Äù lottery) to enable them to take and sell your personal data, and they created various means to force/trick you into signing up whether or not you want to.The trap that I fell into (and plainly am not the first) is that if one signs up for T-Mobile Home Internet service, the only way to configure the T-Mobile router/modem in one‚Äôs home (e.g., to choose a name and password for your WiFi) is to use a specific T-Mobile app on one‚Äôs phone, and one cannot sign into the T-Mobile app without signing up for T-Mobile Tuesdays.  The T-Mobile Tuesdays terms and conditions are a near complete surrender of all of your rights, specifically including the rights to your personal data including your location data.So, T-Mobile is selling an over-the-air carrier service (presumably under an FCC tariff) that is crippled at the user end unless the user agrees to an unbelievably onerous set of terms and conditions that, among other things, allows the disclosure of your personal information.If one thinks that I am kidding about how onerous the terms and conditions are, here are a few quotes (available online on the T-Mobile Tuesdays T&Cs page):‚Äú‚Ä¶ this contract includes indemnities to the Sponsor from you, a limitation of your rights and remedies, binding arbitration of claims, waiver of class action claims and waiver to the right to trial by jury.‚Äù  For those not familiar, ‚Äúindemnities‚Äù is where you agree to be responsible for the problems of T-Mobile Tuesdays ‚Äì you have to take care of the billion-dollar corporation.‚ÄúBy entering the Sweepstakes, Participants unconditionally: [‚Ä¶]  b. grant (and agree to confirm that grant in writing) Sponsor, the Prize Partner and each of their respective designees to use Prize Winner‚Äôs name, photograph, likeness, voice, biographical information, statements and address (city and state) for advertising and/or publicity purposes worldwide and in all forms of media now known or hereafter developed (including, but not limited to publishing the Prize Winner‚Äôs name on Sponsor‚Äôs and the Prize Partner‚Äôs Instagram and/or Facebook pages), in perpetuity, without further compensation, except in Tennessee and where prohibited by law; and c. agree that Participant‚Äôs wireless service provider may release any Participant‚Äôs phone number(s) to the Sponsor or its designees for use in contacting Participant and determining Participant‚Äôs eligibility to receive the prize.‚Äù‚ÄúTo the maximum extent permitted by applicable law, by entering, each Participant (and guest, if applicable) and each of their agents, assignees, executors and successors agree to indemnify, defend, hold harmless and fully release and forever discharge each of the Released Parties and their respective shareholders from and against any and all liabilities, costs, claims, alleged claims, demands, duties, rights, agreements, promises, damages, injuries, losses, expenses, liens and debt actions of any kind, including, without limitation, attorneys‚Äô fees, whether now known or unknown, unforeseen or foreseen, arising out of or in any way connected with, directly or indirectly, participation in the Sweepstakes, including without limitation, personal injury or death, loss of enjoyment, or other harm or loss of any nature whatsoever caused or contributed to by or arising out of participation in this Sweepstakes or resulting from acceptance, possession, quality, use or misuse of a prize. The Released Parties are not responsible for any additional expenses, omissions or delays resulting from any acts of any government or authority.‚Äù  Yep, you get to the pay the attorney fees for these big corporations to defend themselves against any wrongdoing, including a wrong done to you!But hey, at least then you can pick a WiFi name and password for your T-Mobile Home internet.  Congratulations!

I am beyond frustrated with T-Mobile right now. I have been a loyal customer for nearly 22 years. In fact, T-Mobile is the only cell phone provider I have ever been with, and I have sung your praises since I was 16 years old. While that may not mean much to you, word of mouth travels quickly - especially if I go to the media, (which they may or may not care to cover, but I will literally not stop until I'm heard).I have been trying to access my OWN PERSONAL phone records from November of 2022. After much run-around from representatives stating it wasn't possible, I finally spoke with someone from one of your physical locations who not only informed me it is possible, but he also told me how to get them. I wish I could remember his name because I was very grateful for his willingness to help. Per his instructions, I called, "611," and asked for a reprint. Sure enough, that seemed to be all I needed at the time. I was assured I would receive my reprint in the mail within 10 business days.10 business days came and went, and I never received my statement. I called again, and a representative by the name of Angel, was very empathetic. He ordered a 2nd reprint for me, and he even offered to follow up with me within a week to ensure I received them. The week went by, and Angel called as he promised (super grateful for that), but I still hadn't received my reprint. He then told me he would request a manager to upload them and email them to me. He said it might take 24 hrs as they were really busy.I gave them 48 hours to get the job done, and yet nothing happened AGAIN. I called "611" that evening, and I reached a different representative who said they would send another request for management to email my records to me. She said she would call me back the following day at 10:00 AM while a manager was present to ensure it happened. Guess who never received a follow up call...That evening, after work, I called into the "611" line, and I explained the situation once more. I was assured yet another empty promise that I would have my November 2022 statement in my email within 24 hours. Do I have my phone records yet? No. No, I do not.Never, in my wildest dreams, did I ever think that it would be so difficult to request my own personal phone records. DO BETTER, T-Mobile; do better!

This is a PSA for any T-mobile users out there. Watch yourself, cause T-mobile is out here stealing peoples money. I was with them for 2 long years. First, it started off with them telling me they could lower my bill, the price they quoted me was not the price I saw when I got my bills every month, service was ok but definitely not as good as my previous carrier. I knew almost immediately that when the contract was up, I was out! This past November it came time and I jumped to another carrier. They ported numbers over and told me to check with T-mobile to be sure that all lines shut down. December 19th I did just that, mind you it took me 3 hours in store to close because of some pin they said I set up in the initial start that 2 years later, I had never used. I spoke at that time to both in store associates and customer care and both assured me that I would only pay the balance they requested that day to complete the close of all lines. Neither would provide this so called ‚Äúpin‚Äù even with my ID. I thought that would be the end, but a friend mentioned to me that they had something similar happen and their account never closed, causing another bill. Something told me with all the trouble I had with them to check on it. On Jan 29, I went in store to confirm that I was all set. Some how I had a bill larger than a normal monthly bill, I spent about an hour in there arguing with them before agreeing to pay another $288. They credited my account for an additional amount since they had seen that it was an error on their part. I verified several times that this was the last and final bill. Customer care and associates, again say that is correct and I reluctantly pay and leave.Mind you, once you port your numbers T-Mobile shuts down all access to your account and you cannot see or track any bills or payments. Well, it is now August‚Ä¶ I receive a $175 bill from T-Mobile, but this time it comes from a bill collector! What?!? I go back in the store, they pull up all notes and agree that this bill should never have happened, call customer service and discuss my account. They have no explanation, but tell me it‚Äôs my problem, because it‚Äôs gone to collections. I will have to dispute the charge. They cannot help, customer care did not speak to me directly. I‚Äôm not gonna lye, I blew up in the store. To be clear, I NEVER received any bills. The store says they have an old address, but the debt collectors sure knew where to send it. I went home and called customer care myself.These people wouldn‚Äôt even talk to me about my account, because I don‚Äôt know the ‚Äúpin‚Äù to my account. I have always used the same pins for everything, if I had a pin I know exactly what numbers it would be first of all, but no one in the company could or would talk to me about this account. Saying that they can see my account without the pin and don‚Äôt know where the charges came from??? Refusing to take care of or help in anyway! Again they told me I had to go to dispute with the debt collector and hung up in my face, when I told them that I am not dumb and know they can see all things related to my account. I called the debt collector to try to dispute it, and they told me that T-Mobile has to zero the debt out, in order to dispute and if I don‚Äôt pay it, I will see the hit to my credit. I AM PISSED AND WANT EVERYONE WHO DEALS WITH T-MOBILE TO BE AWARE‚Ä¶.IF YOU READ THEIR REVIEWS THIS IS HAPPENING OVER AND OVER TO MULTIPLE PEOPLE. IF YOU GOOGLE IT ALSO SHOWS A CLASS ACTION LAWSUIT AGAINST T-MOBILE FOR WHAT APPEARS TO ALSO BE FRAUDULANT PRACTICES. PLEASE MOVE ACCORDINGLY IF YOU USE THEM FOR YOUR CARRIER. As for me, next step is either the news or a lawyer!Sorry for the long rant, I would hate for y‚Äôall to have to deal with this non-sense!

I had to manually troubleshoot the issue and revert to our original internet service. We wanted to cancel the trial, but were told we needed to visit a T-Mobile store. Due to the 4th of July weekend, we couldn‚Äôt get there until July 8, which was still within the trial period from the second setup.Now, we are being billed for the service despite the numerous issues we encountered. Every attempt to resolve this by phone has resulted in being put on hold or transferred to incorrect departments. This level of customer service is unacceptable and has caused significant disruption to our operations.I would not recommend T-Mobile based on this experience. The lack of effective support and resolution to our problem has been extremely frustrating.

When I finally dropped T-Mobile I was four days into the next billing cycle.  They charge for the for the full month and do not pro rate. I joined T-mobile when it was the "uncarrier" under Jonh Legere.  The service wasn't always great, but they tried, and I wanted to support that.  We were on a family plan, and after about 15 years, and as the kids aged, it made sense for us to switch to a different carrier that better fit our needs.  That's when the nightmare started.I got an letter saying that I never returned a 4G range extender that I received in 2012.  Yes, 4G and 2012.  It had never worked for us, so we returned it to the store at least 7 years ago.   There was no indication on our account that T-Mobile still thought we had it, so I had long since lost any receipt -- it was off the account, so why hold it?So I called T-mobile at least 10 times over 7 months.  First they said they were trying to locate it, then said I'd receive a credit since they found it.  The credit hadn't been issued, so I called again, at which time they said that since they had no record of it, I owed the full original price, plus a late fee, and there was no way to appeal.  Remember: this was a 4G (which is seldom used) device that was over 12 years old and they told me that they would issue a credit ... until today.  Oh, and if I didn't pay, they'd ding my credit rating.So today I paid over $200 to be done forever with T-mobile.  I hope other people have better experiences, and I loved "old"  T-mobile, but I couldn't recommend T-mobile of today.  To say for months that I was all set, then to turn on a dime -- for a device with no value that they should have known I returned -- is (IMO) terrible service, so to anyone who asks, I'd recommend trying another carrier.

I recently had a highly troubling experience with T-Mobile that left me deeply dissatisfied. Somehow, someone managed to gain access to my account. It started with a call from a person impersonating a T-Mobile employee from the loyalty department. They knew all my personal details, including how long I've been with T-Mobile, how many lines I have, my exact monthly bill, and more. They promised me a discount on my bills and even deposited money into my T-Mobile account to appear legitimate.The impersonator offered me two free iPhone 15 1TB devices, but instead, I received iPhone 15s with only 500MB. They tracked the delivery and knew exactly when the phones would arrive. After realizing the mistake, they called to apologize and provided a return address to send the phones back. Everything happened so quickly that it felt like a whirlwind.When I reported the incident to T-Mobile, I expected them to take swift action to resolve the issue. Instead, they informed me that since the phones were delivered to my house and someone in my home signed for them, they are not responsible. Despite my detailed report, T-Mobile refuses to take accountability, leaving me to bear the cost of the phones.This experience has been incredibly frustrating and has shaken my trust in T-Mobile's security measures. Their lack of support in resolving this matter is deeply disappointing, and I am now stuck with a significant financial burden due to their inadequate handling of the situation.

In April 2022, while in Georgia for work, I went to a T-Mobile store to inquire about a wifi hotspot. The representative there told me about a small wifi device they had. I asked if I would be able to try out the device and T-Mobile‚Äôs service to see if it would actually work where I was and if it didn‚Äôt work, return it. He said yes.I signed up and took the device home. After trying the device and service out for 5 days, I was not able to access the internet using it. So, I returned to the store where the same representative helped me. After returning the device, he told me I would not be charged anything else and my service was canceled.For a year following that day, T-Mobile charged me $50 every month. I called them several times to request that they stop withdrawing from my account and refund the money they had taken. They told me that I had to go into a store to be helped with this.So, I went into a store. At the store, they tried to help me by calling T-Mobile‚Äôs Care department. At that point, they said that T-Mobile Care would be taking care of it - that I would not be charged anymore and I would receive a refund. That did not happen.I followed up with the store manager after yet another payment was taken out of my account. By this time it was March 2023, almost 1 year after the first charge! I never received a response from her.So, in late March of 2023, I went to my bank and asked that they place a stop payment on T-Mobile‚Äôs monthly draft from my account. They did that and refunded a portion of the money that T-Mobile wrongfully took from my account.T-Mobile has now (as of 6/17/24) reported me to a collection agency stating that I owe them $378! I do not owe T-mobile any money and in fact, they still owe me over $300!I wish I would have thought to place the stop payment with my bank after the first fraudulent charge by T-Mobile. Regardless, beware of T-Mobile.

Long story-read if you don't want this to happen to you. When issues go on endlessly for years ‚Äì it's not just a once or twice fluke nor can tower location always be to blame. So tired of hearing, ‚Äúit's the towers‚Äù ‚Äúit's the tower location‚Äù. Then fix tower problem or stop selling in this area.I know some people say it works so good. Some win the lottery too. Doesn't mean it's a common occurrence! Looking at tmobile rating here seems the chance of it being ‚Äúso good‚Äù is same as hitting lottery jackpot. Millions to one! I truly don't know where tmobile gets those best of stats. NO ONE I mention tmobile to has anything good to say about them.Unfortunately we got it all ‚Äì internet, 2 phones & watches. Tmobile internet & cell service is unreliable. No matter if home, out locally or some other city we could not count on having reliable cell service. We had 2 identical phones & side by side could have different connectivity issues. 1 working, other might not. Might work one trip, not the next. Not always same phone or in same location ‚Äì just whenever either couldn't connect. Phones also would say no internet connection available when it should be cell not WiFi anyway. Later in same location it would work. Cant find directions or businesses without connection. At times no cell service at all, was garbled or dropped calls.With so many problems & internet outages I took photos & videos. Basically anytime you turned on a device requiring tmobile you knew it would probably lose connection at least once or something else. An hour show might go out 5 or 6 times, every day & at all times of the day. My photo file got so large I had to stop. Local office still looked at me as if I had 2 heads even after viewing videos of what I was telling them. Didn't care.Being so unreliable, I would not give a child a tmobile phone. I'd also discourage travelers especially those who go alone or need to rely on cell service.For travel safety & being locked into a contract, we got a prepaid account from competitor to compare with tmobile. Competitor passed consistently with flying colors, every time & everywhere! Like we knew, it was just tmobile failure. And it's not like we're in some remote part of the world or well below sea level etc. We live in town, not country. We couldn't wait to dump tmobile! We also tested internet ‚Äì competitor works. They offer free internet booster if it doesn't work throughout house! Price is only a bit more, but we now have an internet system that works. Watching an hour program doesn't take 2 hours now.  Cheaper isn't better if it doesn't reliably work.When phones paid off & the "no contracts" contract part of bill paid off - we canceled all services May 11, 2024. Was paid up to date at that time as of recent auto-pay. Only charges from then to May 11 were now due. Said final bill will be sent. DON'T cancel before you stop auto-pay & remove payment method. It's how they overbill you. Make copies of anything important on your online account. You cannot access your online account once it's canceled. You'll be told changes have to be made online, then told if number canceled, there's no online account now. No one will help. This allows them to create charges & bill since most people don't double check for accuracy.Not being able to remove payment method, through BBB contact from tmobile Sr. Specialist Team, CEO. She took auto-pay off & most importantly reviewed account to give what was actually owed. Said made notes on account but was confident final bill would now be correct amount. Told us wait & contact her if amount was different.Arrived 6/5/24 amt almost doubled. Contacted. She got back to us with true amount owed & how to pay now there is no online account access on about 6/6. We paid this amount due within a few days. After all today is only 6/12/24. Wasn't paid today or yesterday.Tmobile is horrible!! Recap - Account current. Last auto pay 4/21 next would've been 5/21 ‚Äì but canceled tmobile 5/11. Received final bill abt 6/5 still wrong amount due ‚Äì contacted home office immediately & paid within days of actual amount due. Today ‚Äì 6/12, just a month from our cancellation date - I receive a letter from collection agency dated 6/5 on behalf of tmobile for a crazy amount & fee on top of it for service on a paid up to date account that WE cancelled. Date of their letter shows tmobile had to contact them well before 6/5 for agency to create/mail me letter dated 6/5! Really? I am furious!!I work hard on my credit rating (another stupid thing for only businesses to legally way overcharge consumer since it's damned if you pay your bills off & damned if you don't) to have a company like this so blatantly abuse the system!!For mobile/internet service that is reliable & works - forget tmobile exists! - Just remember t-mobile service (for me) stands for Terrible Mobile Service! Go elsewher

T-Mobile Business Internet is (still) a mess and a joke.As both a T-Mobile Home Internet user AND T-Mobile Business Internet user, it is astounding how different the user experience is for both products.  Through my experience, it is straight forward and simple on the T-Mobile Home Internet side to have questions answered, access my account, and to ultimately receive internet.On the contrary, the business process is a mess.  For one, you work through a representative, which sounds good in theory to have that personal experience; however, that representative changed hands 4 times in the first year.  So, when they "accidentally" sent me 3 boxes and charged me separately for all 3 lines, you would think they'd have documentation and process in place for handing things off when a representative changes.  Nope.  Not at all.  Not only did it require multiple e-mails and phone calls to explain the situation, the previous representative was told to "no longer work my account" by their manager, so they couldn't step in and help if they wanted to (so I'm told).  Just an odd way to conduct business if you want to provide that "personal" touch through representatives.Adding another layer of poor a poor user experience.  There is a business support line (which, makes sense as representatives don't want to handle the simple day-to-day things like changing a password), but the issue here is the inconsistency of both sides forwarding you to the other for things that are above a password reset and below needing a new product.  It's incredibly frustrating as a user of this product.Oh - one more example of how poor the business home internet processes are.  When selling my business and changing hands, instead of transferring the my device and my account to the new owner, they sent him a new device and added that device onto my account.  So although I was able to cancel my device, my account remained active receiving charges from the new device they sent the new business owner.  All through this, no communication was received on my end.It's just shocking to me how poor the Business Internet process and experience is relative to the Home Internet.  Could not contrast more.

My family and I have been T-Mobile customers for over 20 years. On April 15 2024 my iPhone 13 Pro suddenly went into SOS mode. Meaning my phone lost service. I have not been connected to the T-Mobile network that I pay for since then. Since April 15, I have spent countless hours everyday, basically spending every moment of free time that I have calling T-Mobile tech-support to resolve this issue. I have been on multiple calls with Verizon and T-Mobile to resolve this issue. Apparently my IMEI number was blocked by Verizon, although I have never been a Verizon customer, like I mentioned above, my family, and I have only ever been T-Mobile customers for decades. Verizon has confirmed that they have unblocked my IMEI, they even confirm that with a T-Mobile supervisor on a conference call with me. I was told by the tech associate that they would call me back on a working line, knowing that my phone didn‚Äôt work, and apparently they called my blocked phone line and left a message which is another example of the carelessness and neglect of T-Mobile and my issue. Every single time I call I‚Äôm having to re-explain myself and I‚Äôve been extremely patient with each and every T-Mobile representative I‚Äôve spoken to never raising my voice and always respectful, but I am at my absolute limit. After multiple T-Mobile representatives have promised me with callbacks with solutions and never hearing back. I feel like this company doesn‚Äôt care about this major inconvenience, stress causing, and dangerous situation this issue has become. As a young woman in my 20s, not having any cell phone service for over a week while having to work an hour away from home has made me feel extremely unsafe and uncared for by T-Mobile as a company. I am traveling in two days and feel immensely anxious and unsafe with the idea of being out of state with no phone service. If something happens to me during my travels, how will I be able to contact my family? How is that okay?  This has affected my every day peace of mind. At this point, my entire family is ready to leave T-Mobile due to the absolute disappointment of the handling of this issue. I don‚Äôt believe it‚Äôs fair that I would have to pay for an upgrade for a new phone, which is what I‚Äôve been told is my only immediate solution, when I have a iPhone 13 Pro in perfect condition. I am being forced to pay a new phone due to T-Mobile‚Äôs inability to solve an issue that is not my fault? That is unfair. I was told I was eligible for a warranty trade-in and then within 24 hours told I was not due to the issue being escalated and having to be seen through.I don‚Äôt think a $20 credit or a warranty replacement is worth all the time and energy I have put in by trying to fix this issue, especially as an extremely loyal T-Mobile customer, who has done nothing but treat the T-Mobile staff with upmost respect during this very frustrating issue, after the countless promises of call backs and solutions that not a single T-Mobile associate has kept.

T-Mobile has deceptive trade practices, fraudulent ads and guarantees which they do not honor, and their websites and customer service agents lie.I thought you folks would be interested in the recent experience I had with T-Mobile.Having spotty cell service with our current cell carrier, I was looking at competitive services on my smartphone on April 6 and I came across T-Mobile. Their pricing is quite competitive. I then came across a feature on their phone accessed web site that pushed me to try them.The Go Back Guarantee: On the phone version of their website, they had a large ad, ‚ÄúYou'll love it here, guaranteed. With our new $50 Go Back Guarantee, if you're not satisfied within 30 days, you can switch back to your old carrier and get $50 for every voice line. Via virtual prepaid Master card. Allow 5 weeks for card. Get full terms (hyperlink)‚ÄùThe Go Back Guarantee Full Terms: ‚ÄúYou'll love it here, guaranteed. Contact us before cancelling or porting out line(s) to request payout. Limited time offer; subject to change. Port-in voice line from postpaid plan w/ eligible carrier (i.e., AT&T, Verizon, Spectrum, Claro, Liberty, Xfinity or US Cellular), and port-out to eligible carrier within 30 days of T-Mobile line activation required. Account must be in good standing (e.g., final bill paid) to receive virtual prepaid MasterCard (no cash access & expires in 6 months). Up to 12/account. One offer per subscriber. Not available for customers that cancelled T-Mobile service within the past 90 days. Card is issued by Sunrise Banks N.A., Member FDIC, pursuant to a license from Mastercard(sic) International Incorporated. Use of this card constitutes acceptance of the terms and conditions stated in the Cardholder Agreement.‚ÄùI showed my wife and her sister this guarantee and they agreed it was worth a try.I went to their store on April 7 and got their service.By April 11, it was evident T-Mobile wasn't working for us.I went to the store who told me to contact Customer Care by phone.The Customer Care agent eventually handed me over to a supervisor who repeated what the CC agent was telling me, ‚ÄúThis guarantee promotion didn't start until today (April 11) and cannot be honored for service purchased prior.‚Äù The supervisor claimed he didn't see the Go Back Guarantee on the website even though I told him where it was within the web site to see it, but he claimed he didn't see it.  He said T-Mobile could not honor the guarantee.  Per the guarantee, I had yet to cancel T-Mobile, nor had I started service with another carrier.Since then, the guarantee has been removed from the desktop website, though it still exists on the phone website.  Regardless, T-Mobile refuses to back up the advertised guarantee.Per T-Mobile's advertised guarantee, they owe me $100 (for two lines), a guarantee they refuse to honor.How many others have had the 'promotion' not start until AFTER their service has started???

I called UPS they said well the driver can change route to save fuel. I said but wait customers don‚Äôt know the driver is coming 5 or 6 hours ahead of a scheduled time. Her response Sorry, they will come Friday I said but no one will be there her response then they will send it back to T-Mobile. In the process UPS mishandled the phone and did not return it to T-Mobile.So now third trip to T-Mobile again everything cancelled, and order reconstructed. Only this time I had it sent to work a warehouse where people do receiving all day and UPS is their main shipper. So, Tuesday 3/5/2024 I get confirmation package delivered at dock at 9:37 am. Went down to dock and no package. They said the auto sign has been happening since covid and driver still does it. The warehouse Manager said sometimes they do this then deliver it the next day. I called UPS they said dispatch would call within an hour, no call. I am writing this letter of complaint because of the unsatisfactory customer service treatment that I received at your store located at 3204 Pennsylvania Avenue SE. I visited the store on Saturday March 2, 2024 and spoke with one of the store representatives. I explained to her that my phone was not working, it had been not holding a charge and finally, went all the way down. She checked the phone and confirmed that the phone was not functioning. She prompted me to make a claim and provided me with a phone to call the claims Department. I proceeded accordingly, and the claim was approved with a $49.00 deductible paid.  My wife opted to have the phone sent to the store for pick-up. I was informed that the phone had arrived at the store and proceeded to pick the phone up at around 10:45 AM on Monday March 4, 2024. The store representative asked a few questions regarding my claim, which I thought was odd, since I had already been through that process. The store representatives requested my identification to verify my identification. After a while, she told me that she couldn‚Äôt scan the phone into the system, only the manger had the credentials to take such actions. Therefore, I returned home and went back to the store around 12:35 PM. I was told that the manager had not arrived and was told to return around 2:30. I asked if a regional manger can perform the activity necessary for me to retrieve my phone. I was told no; only the store manger could perform this activity. I waited approximately 35 additional minutes for the store manager to arrive. When I returned to the store, there was a waiting period and then additional questions were asked by the store representative. After a while, the store representative told me that the claim was denied. I was very perplexed because the claim had already been approved. Therefore, I requested to contact the claims department to ascertain what had transpired between my claim being approved to the store denying my claim. The T-Mobile claim representative spoke with the manger, Abdul, because she said that the claim had been approved. After a few more moments, the store representative began to asked additional questions and requested my identification again, now I am not only perplexed, confused but also annoyed. Finally, Abdul informed me that the claim had been denied and proceeded to cancel the order.I am thankful that the customer service department responded by re-ordering the phone and refund my deductible. However, I remain concern regarding this unsatisfactory level of customer service, since this is the T-Mobile store that is closest to my house. I am hoping that this issue is corrected, that I may not experience such horrible services the next time I visit this location.Feel free to contact me should you need to discuss this matter.

As a long-standing T-Mobile customer subscribed to the Magenta¬Æ Amplified plan with three voice lines, my experience with the company has been consistently positive without any notable issues. However, on January 15, 2024, we initiated contact with T-Mobile to help us navigate plans and get the best deal possible at that time.  To stay on the current plan and purchase all new phones and increase our monthly bill from $ 157 to $270 or switch to a more expensive plan and get promotions. We opted to switch to the Go5G Next plan, which involved trading in three devices: upgrading from an iPhone 12 to an iPhone 15 Pro and obtaining one complimentary iPhone 15 due to adding a line. During this process, 2 different T-Mobile representatives assured us that, after factoring in all eligible discounts, including a teacher discount, our monthly bill would total $230. The process included 3 steps including changing the plan which is only possible by phone service. We trusted representatives to do it correctly, but unfortunately, it was not the case. The wrong code was applied to one of the lines, the other code was expired and had no value.Despite receiving three new iPhone 15 Pros and one iPhone 15 on January 17, our account still reflected details from the previous Magenta plan. It was only last week that T-Mobile finally updated our account to the Go5G Next plan, resulting in a monthly bill exceeding $349. It feels that we are trapped because according to the agreement we only have 20 days to make changes, but our account information was not updated till it was too late. Until that time (February 6) we were sure that our bill would be $230, not $349 like it is stated now.Upon noticing this discrepancy, I promptly contacted T-Mobile to seek a resolution. Despite investing significant time on the phone with various representatives, the issue with our bill persisted unresolved. I hate to be trapped: phones we used for trade-in cannot be returned to us, and codes for the trade-in are incorrect. The customer service department wasted hours on ‚Äúinvestigation‚Äô to come up with ‚ÄúUnfortunately we cannot fix the problem as all those deals are expired now.

Then my husband put in for the first responder discount and auto pay discount and she said the bill would lower to $135 within 1 to 3 days. It did not. Once our contract is up, we will be leaving tmobile for good and i would NEVER recommend anyone go there, especially the lanoka harbor nj store. We upgraded our devices to the iPhone 15 Pro with dual e-sim slots and upgraded our service plans accordingly to Go5G Plus which would make is eligible for upgrades every 2 yrs and with the promo would pay off the phones over those 2 yrs. However, if you wanted to take advantage of the second e-sim slot e.g. for international travel to be able to use foreign networks for faster data and calls while abroad, you couldn‚Äôt. If you needed a second e-sim you have to have the phone paid outright AND the device must be used with T-mobile for at least 40 days according to T-mobile‚Äôs current policies. It‚Äôs not an issue if you added a second T-mobile line to the phone but good luck if you want to use it for travel outside Can or Mex. If you stick to the promo where T-mobile eventually pays off the cost of the phone over 2 years (via monthly credits), you would never be able to access the second e-sim unless you held on to your now 2yr old phone and chose not to upgrade. We have spent hours with customer service trying to explain our needs so that we can use the second e-sim slot: we paid off 2 iPhone 15s, we even said they could re-lock the phones after we added our foreign e-sim. Only under the threats of leaving T-mobile did we get contacts from higher level reps who have now promised us twice that they would unlock the phones. At the time of this review, we have still not gotten any results or updates within the timeframe of their ‚Äúpersonal guarantees.‚Äù Meanwhile, we are living abroad with less than optimum T-mobile service (using their local partner network). Some local businesses and services we use here require a local number which we have (because we had local plans before we switched devices and plans) but can no longer use or access them since we can‚Äôt add the second e-sim.TLDR: International travelers beware. T-Mobile policies don‚Äôt make things easy. You can‚Äôt use the phone to its full potential. Customer service has not kept its promises.

Back in about 2009 T-Mobile sold my personal information. As my contract was coming to an end I was contacted by phone by someone asking if I wanted to renew my contract. I went ahead assuming it was T-Mobile at the time, but it turned out to be '3' Mobile and I didn't realise they had sold my details until I read about it, and being naive about mobile phone companies, I thought that '3' were part of T-mobile. I only found out about the data being sold by reading about it in the papers at the time. Needless to say I haven't used T-mobile nor '3' mobile ever since. However, we are now in 2023 and I'm still receiving scam and spam emails from all the usual culprits at the rate of some 15-20 a day. It is so brazen that they always quote a reference number and guess what? It is is the last 9 digits of that original T-Mobile number I had so there is no escaping who is to blame. Beware they will sell your personal details! Also '3' Mobile need a mention too as they bought those stolen details, so don't trust them either. I've left this for so long but after all this time I've finally had enough and the fallout from a company that still drags on. Don't go to tmobile, they are liars and don't know what information they are advertising!  I had an account with ATT for 10+ years and I was getting charged over $400/month for tv, internet, and phone.  I went up to midtown plaza to tmobile when the store was there to switch my provider.  Gabby, the store manager, assisted me.  She told me I could switch over to t-mobile for a lot cheaper for all services and I could trade my ATT phones and they would be all paid off, in full.  I had two phones from ATT, an iphone and an android that I traded in.  No further instruction was given, they said they would take care of it, and received a confirmation email of the same!  4 months later, I am getting a bill from ATT that I owe for the phones that were switched over, over $1000.00!  I kept calling Gabby and she kept saying she would look into it.  After several months, now I am in collections and my credit that I worked so hard to get back up, is ruined.  Apparently, Gabby, keep in mind she is a manager, had the wrong information.  Because I was on a payment plan, the phones were not eligible for this program!  Shouldn't a manger know this?  After all the back and forth, and finally finding this out, btw, noone knew this info up front, I attempted to call Gabby again, but this time, no response.  Why? In my opinion, T-Mobile is the worst customer service I have ever dealt with. Sprint was transferred to Tmobile. Our old phone carrier shut down so we were forced to change carriers. I went to a T-Mobile store in Maize, KS and Maria, the lady that helped me, told me we would definitely have 5G coverage where we live. I questioned her about that several times during our interaction because my husband and I live very rural and when I looked at the coverage map before heading into the store, coverage looked spotty. She kept telling me we would FOR SURE have 5G coverage. I didn't purchase a new phone until I knew it would work at our house. After a couple weeks, I decided to purchase a new device with them because we at least had 4G coverage. Then, shortly after the 14 day return period expired, our service is almost nonexistent. I called customer service and the guy I spoke to informed me that he would have never sold us a plan and phones because his map showed almost no coverage where we live. He told me that we basically get "left over" signals from a tower that is very far away from us and the reason we don't have service now is because they were having problems with said tower. I asked when the tower was going to be up and he said he didn't know. Now, we don't get service, thank goodness we have wifi or my new expensive phone (that they won't let me pay off early or return) would be a paper weight. The only way out from under them now is to pay off mine and my husband's devices at full retail pricing, not just the sale pricing. My husband's phone hasn't even left the box, but we can't return it. I asked the customer service guy if there's anything we can do since we don't have service and he said, "No, nothing." So basically we have to pay ridiculous prices to them but our phones only work on wifi, that we also have to pay for. I'm extremely disappointed with T-Mobile. We'll be switching to Verizon as soon as we're able to.

I've been a TMobile customer for over 20 years, since it was Aerial, back in 1997.For more than 6 months, I've been paying late fees because my payment due date was originally the 13th of each month and I usually make my payment when I get paid on the 15th of each month. In August, I contacted TMobile Customer Service  to request my payment due date to be changed to at least the 15th of each month. For my surprise, after I was informed that the change was made, the following bill (September) was still reflecting the 10th as the due date for the payments. I patiently contacted TMobile Customer Service once again and supposedly, the issue was resolved, but I still had to pay the late charges. When I received the notification for the October payment, once again, the due date reflected is the 10th. I contacted TMobile again and I was given a credit so ok. I was also explained that I could schedule a payment on October 15th or 16th, as a payment arrangement, and that the November payment was to be due as requested, on or after the 15th of each month. For my surprise, and once again, I just received the notification about my bill with a due date of 11/10th and this time the total amount due is $20 higher than the last amount paid.I contacted customer service once again, this time yelling and screaming to whom identified himself as a Supervisor, Brandon, who stated that he was able to change the due date but I will still be responsible to pay the November bill on the 10th. He offered a $20 credit (A JOKE, AN INSULT) as damage control. Ridiculous.I'm not asking for $20.  I'm asking to get the due date fixed. I feel it is unfair that after over 20 years of paying on time, I need to keep paying late fees due to the incompetency of the TMobile's staff, where nobody seems to be able to make a simple change to an account. As a mortgage loan processor, I know the importance of paying on time; however, looks like TMobile is unwilling to help in order to keep collecting late fees.

We had T-Mobile internet service for 19 months.  The T-Mobile service at the beginning was pretty good, with the service freezing needing a restart only about once a week. However, the towards the end in August of 2023, the gateway(modem) needed to be restarted several times a day in order to function. Around the same time T-Mobile removed the $5 discount for auto pay if you were using a credit card. Something they had allowed for over a year. On Aug 23rd we ordered Xfinity. The Xfinity gateway would be delivered in several days. On Aug 24th, 2023 I called customer service and told them I wished to cancel. However, customer service said I needed to try a new gateway first to see if that would correct the problem. I figured I would compare them both. T-Mobile sent a replacement quickly, but it did not do much better with Mbps download of 44.  The Xfinity gateway came a few days later with Mbps in the 400's for downloads without any problems. I canceled T-Mobile service on Sept 2, 23 through their customer service. When canceling they requested the 6 digit number that I gave them when I signed up 19 months earlier.  I gave them the number I had written down in my T-Mobile file. The customer service rep said it was the wrong number. I said that is the one I uses. They said it was imperative that I give them the 6-digit code.  I asked if they could use my soc sec number or email me a reset and they said no. They said that I would have to physically go to a T-Mobile store and request my 6-digit number after they verified my identity.  I drove to the nearest store located at 2024 IL-50 Ste A1, Bourbonnais IL 60914 and spoke with a rep named Michael.  He said he could not give me the 6-digit number and told me to call customer service back and tell them so. I went home and called and told them what he said, and they said okay and that they would email a return label for the gateway.  I received the email with the label on September 2nd, 2023 and returned the gateway to UPS. T-Mobile received the gateway on Sept 11 23.  I received a letter stating that "They received the gateway, and no further action is needed on your part." Then on Sept 19, 23 T-Mobile collected an auto pay of $55 from my credit card on file.  I called my credit card to dispute the charge.  T-Mobile sent me a new bill asking for the $55, plus $25 for a chargeback, Plus the next months $55 for a total of $135.  I called customer service on Oct 7, 23, and they said I needed to go to an actual store because they could not help me again because of the 6-digit pin saying the one I gave them was incorrect. I went to the store in Bradley Il and they told me that the account had never been canceled, even though customer service sent the return label and had received the gateway. The store contacted T-mobile customer service from their store and eventually a very rude corporate manager named Patrick said that they insisted I pay the full $135.  I explained I had cancelled the service on Sept 2, 23 and returned the gateway.  He said it was T-Mobiles' policy to have you also physically come to the store to cancel and that it wasn't officially canceled until that day which was over a month later. I told him I physically went to the T-Mobile store but Michael would not give me the pin.  He scolded me saying I should have used the phrase "I wish to have you cancel my account" I explained that I had already done that with customer service rep on the phone and that I had told Michael that I needed the pin number for them to cancel it. Patrick from Corporate says that I am repeating myself and it was my fault for not saying that I wanted Michael to cancel the account.  He then said that he would offer me a one-time deal that he would forgive the last months charge and that he was being very gracious in doing so.  I again told him I didn't even have a gateway to use the service and that T-Mobile had it after sending me the return email and label. He again said it was never fully canceled to their satisfaction whatever that means.  We went round and round until I said I would pay $55 for the month I disputed even though I had canceled the service just to end the madness. He said he also insisted on the $25. I said no and that I wanted to only pay $55 only on that day.  He said it would cost an additional $10 to have an operator take my payment.  I asked if I could do it online without a charge and he said yes but it would not give me a confirmation.  Because he was not helpful at all we ended the call.  I went home and paid $55 online and still received a confirmation number. It seemed that Patrick was trying to squeeze even more money from me. The amount of time and effort I have put into resolving this is ridicules. There appears to be no training for customer service either at the store level or at corporate.Update 10/15/23  T-Mobile reached out and we reached a mutual understanding.

In November 2021, I traded-in 3 phones (family plan) for a total trade-in value of $2400 ($800 each) at T-mobile. T-mobile promised to return the $2400 in the form of a one time credit and further credits spread over 30 months. However, I have had to call in dozens of time spending close to 50 hours on the phone with them to get the credits. Each time, I'm promised a refund only to see a small partial credit. Each time, I argue with the company to honor the contract, I'm assured a refund of the payments due.After I filed a on the phone  complaint with the FCC, t-mobile now tells me they will honor the trade in credit but start the 30 month cycle 13 months after the original contract date. They are not willing to give in writing Tbey abrogated the contract.Given this is affecting thousands of customers, it is possible T-mobile swindles customers of a couple of billion $ every year.If we get more than 40 customers willing to go to court, we could file a class action lawsuit against T-mobile?

I've been a customer for 16 years. I recently switched companies. I canceled my service 3 days before the start of my billing cycle in July. In August, I noticed a charge to my bank account for a full month's service, which was canceled over a month prior. I was told that even though the number had been switched over for 3 days, the account was closed the day that the billing cycle started. How convenient! After spending over 1.5 hours talking to reps, telling me I need to go into a physical location (more inconvenience) for me, they acknowledged that if anything, I should have been billed at a pro-rated rate of just one day.  I disagreed and the supervisor rep finally told me they would credit my account the full payment amount, not even pro-rated. I called my bank and had them halt the payment of the charge because T-Mobile was able to take my money in a day but it would take up to 10 business days to return my money.Fast-forward to a few weeks later, and we get a bill in the mail for the full-amount, plus an additional $30 fee. We called T-Mobile again and had another supervisor waive the entire fee, which was supposed to have been waived a few weeks prior. This time we recorded the call at least.Fast-forward to last night and we got yet another bill in the mail from T-Mobile. Called and they said we had a $0 balance and all was resolved. We chalked it up to the previous call being made after that last bill was sent to us.Today we received a letter from a collections agency from T-Mobile. So in a month and a half of the bill being "late" (even though they admitted 2 times being in the wrong), they sent us to collections.I've had perfect credit my entire life, and T-Mobile is trying to do what they can to change that over their mistake. This is how they treated a long-time loyal customer. Disgusting company.

We switched to Tmobile in Aug 2023 and wanted to love it.  Unfortunately, we felt misled at best and tricked at worst.  Now we are stuck for 2 years.1.  We were quoted a plan price (written down by sales salesperson).  We got a text saying sign up for automatic payments and you will get another $5 discount per line.  Come to find out, if we did not sign up for auto-payment it would cost more. No discount there. Bait and Switch.2. One line could not be activated the first day we purchased the other two phones.  Based on sales rep advice, we activated the line and they would roll the activated number to an actual new phone the following weekend.  We were charged for 2 activation fees.3.  The quoted price for the phones we traded in was inaccurate - to the tune of $400 less than quoted.4.  The customer service rep was very rude when we tried to understand what was going on and he basically said we should have known what the phone was worth and that when the phone was sent in, someone made the decision.  (We can understand if it was broken or water damaged of course the value should be reduced, but really if your employees do not know the value of a phone or mislead, or lie about the value, isn't that on the company??5.  Coverage across rural SD and MN is not good.  Dropped calls several times over the miles.6.  So after month 2 bill, the cost is much higher than expected.  Oh yes and be sure your tech skills are strong as you will have to navigate their website and the app.
